item.title: Need rain and thunder sample
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
You’ll probably find many, many options on Freesound.org.

 

I try to make piano and guitars in Auxy sound more realistic instead of something done on Auxy

It’s perhaps not so hard if the piano is buried within an EDM piece. But, for extended piano sequences or entire pieces, as soon as you have a few notes in a tight sequence, the quantisation and lack of volume or velocity options starts to become more apparent, killing the emotion and illusion of performance - imo.

I’ve not heard an Auxy piano piece that I’d consider to have successfully got beyond the sound of MIDI sequencing. Some very nice compositions, but just sounding like demo programs on an electrionic keyboard.

Guitar suffers from the same problems - in practice.

 

a huge element missing from sweeper. The THUNDER!!

I was surprised that Azure didn’t suggest using one of the Impacts as thunder.

item.title: Need rain and thunder sample
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Agreed.
There can be charm in ‘cheap’ emulations. They have their own character which can be interesting.

Whether it’s every non-sample-based drum machine ever or synth presets for Brass, Strings, etc… they all have their merits. But it’s the timbral variance of real instruments* and natural sounds that have proved hard to emulate convincingly. It’s very easy to stray into less than convincing territory.

If that’s something the OP would like to have, the @AzureOnyx’s suggestion might do the trick. If not, then 3rd-party samples or custom field recordings are the way to go.

 
(* It’s partly why I have an issue with most Auxy piano (and guitar) pieces. The lack of timbral variance (and performance nuance) makes most pieces starkly unconvincing to my ears. It takes me out of the ‘listening to a piano’ mode and quickly throws me back into the ‘listening to Auxy’ mode. It more or less conspicuous depending on the style and genre.)

Anyhoo…
